passages.text: Fifteen years since the original passage of the Dodd- Frank Act, regulatory requirements have been implemented around margin and capital, aiming to enhance financial stability and reduce systemic risk in the financial sector. Over time, frameworks such as the uncleared margin rules (UMR) and Basel III prudential standards have shifted the trading landscape for over- the- counter (OTC) and exchange- traded derivatives markets.

In this quarterly report, the FICC Market Structure & Liquidity Strategy team considers how global policy actions have prompted the search for cost savings and execution efficiencies among market participants. Building on these themes, we explore whether certain product advancements have facilitated the use of listed derivatives across FX, fixed income and commodities markets.

Nearing a decade since the phased rollout of UMR began[1]in 2016, optimizing margin and collateral management have been a central focus as firms managed the increased initial margin (IM) for uncleared OTC derivatives. The last phase of UMR went live in 2022 and scoped in the most firms, as it included those with derivatives in excess of \(\) 8\$ billion in aggregate average notional.

As more market participants have come into scope for UMR, additional capital has been set aside to satisfy the margin requirements, affecting profitability. According to a recent International Swaps & Derivatives Association (ISDA) survey, IM and variation margin collected by leading derivatives market participants for their non- cleared derivatives exposures increased by \(6.4\%\) to \(\) 1.5\$ trillion at the end of 2024.[2]In addition, initial margin posted for non- cleared derivatives rose to \(\) 328\$ billion at the end of 2024.[3]
Figure 1: Initial margin posted by ISDA survey participants (USD billion)

In many non- cleared derivatives markets, bilateral IM is often calculated using the ISDA Standard Initial Margin Model (ISDA SIMM), which establishes industry standard methodology to help reduce the risk of disputes between counterparties. [4] There are benefits to using a consistent standardized framework that is recognized by global regulators, but the need for margin cost reduction has been an equally challenging aspect for market participants. This was a key theme at the ISDA annual meeting in May, where industry stakeholders discussed ways to enhance collateral efficiency amid elevated margin call and settlement volumes. [5]

With collateral requirements contributing to rising costs, market participants are seeking methods to optimize for margin requirements across OTC derivative portfolios. Driven by the pursuit of capital and operational efficiencies, traders have increasingly leveraged listed derivatives such as futures and options that can offer margin savings, operational efficiencies and streamlined market access.

In the evolving FX landscape, in addition to UMR, the Standardized Approach for Counterparty Credit Risk (SA- CCR) has led to higher bank capital requirements for counterparty credit risk, particularly for short- dated FX swaps and forwards (see our report on this topic).

A block trade is a permissible, off- exchange, privately negotiated transaction either at or exceeding an exchange determined minimum threshold quantity of futures or options contracts which is executed at a fair and reasonable price apart and away from the central limit order book.

EFRPs involve the simultaneous execution of a futures transaction and an equivalent related position. EFRP transactions are permitted to be executed outside of the exchange's centralized market, with several subtypes including:
Exchange of futures for physical (EFP) Exchange of futures for risk (EFR) Exchange of option for option (EOO)

There is growing awareness that FX clearing can be an effective way to navigate evolving trading economics and regulatory requirements. As we highlighted in a recent Insights report, cleared OTC FX trading volume has increased in recent years, primarily driven by non- deliverable forwards (NDFs).

For those seeking portfolio efficiency, momentum is building among dealer- to- client offerings that facilitate FX clearing while utilizing OTC liquidity. Block trades (blocks) and exchange for related positions (EFRPs) represent emerging mechanisms for maximizing trading efficiency through margin offsets. Blocks and EFRPs enable execution of trades through OTC markets with chosen liquidity providers (LPs), leveraging established relationships and processes while managing risk in a centrally cleared environment.

The EFRP product uses OTC liquidity to clear FX risk in an exchange listed format, allowing a market participant to convert OTC FX spot or forward positions into futures or options post trade. A common EFRP use case involves a market participant placing an OTC FX order with its LP, and once the terms are agreed upon, the OTC position is converted into futures on the exchange.
Figure 2: EFRP example workflow
Source: J.P. Morgan, 2025.

For example, the market participant could agree to sell an EUR/USD FX forward position (OTC) and simultaneously buy an equivalent position in EUR/USD FX futures. In a reverse EFRP, the market participant holds the future that is then converted to cash FX.

While these products are not new, traditional workflows have often necessitated manual intervention for pricing, booking, and posting positions to the exchange. However, advancements in electronic FX execution and workflow automation have begun to reduce the need for these manual processes. These process improvements coupled with the prioritization of margin efficiency may be contributing to the increased demand for blocks and EFRPs.
Figure 3: CME block and EFRP average daily volume (USD notional)

EFRP activity has risen significantly in recent years, with average daily volumes at CME increasing by over \(400\%\) since Q3 of 2023. To further explore the drivers behind this growth, we consider certain product characteristics. EFRPs convert OTC derivatives into centrally cleared products, which removes the need to post collateral on an FX position. Liquidity providers are also able to obtain favorable capital and balance sheet treatment to help alleviate the capital costs of UMR and SA- CCR. As shown in Figure 4, further margin efficiencies may also be available for those trading listed derivatives in FX and interest rates at the same exchange.
Figure 4: CME: FX vs. rates derivatives margin offsets

2-Year UST Note5-Year UST Note10-Year UST NoteUltra 10-Year UST NoteUST BondUltra UST BondAustralian Dollar35%45%50%50%50%55%British Pound55%60%60%60%55%55%Canadian Dollar45%55%55%55%50%55%Euro40%60%60%55%55%55%Japanese Yen25%35%45%45%50%55%Mexican Peso50%50%55%60%55%55%Swiss Franc50%50%55%60%55*55%
For those trading FX as well as Treasury futures and options at CME, up to \(60\%\) margin offsets are available. [6]

In an EFRP transaction, customers access OTC FX liquidity through selected sell- side dealers to obtain an exchange- traded derivative position. This workflow preserves the relationship- driven execution style favored by many buy- side desks, while offering the ability to use non- standardized dates and central clearing.

Certain hedge fund managers and systematic accounts have considered listed FX products in order to bring margin efficiencies to both hedging and directional positions. These market participants may trade FX hedges through a Treasury function or face leverage constraints related to margin use within specific portfolios or pods, perhaps making EFRPs an appealing tool for managing these challenges.

For asset managers who already trade FX futures, EFRPs might enable access to a broader pool of OTC liquidity when executing large futures transactions. The ability to hedge FX exposure back to a benchmark, such as MSCI futures, could be attractive to asset managers seeking to align portfolios with market indices. Additionally, EFRPs might offer a pathway to futures liquidity for certain CTAs or managed accounts that are restricted from holding cash.

Some market participants may prefer to leverage OTC liquidity while maintaining their existing futures- based workflows. In an immediately offsetting EFRP (IOE) scenario, the buy- side trader submits a futures order ticket and receives a futures fill through a principal- to- principal block mechanism on the exchange. The IOE does not require a prior cash booking against the client and allows for immediate unwinding of the cash leg while benefitting from minimized market impact.
Figure 5: Immediately offsetting EFRP workflow
Source: J.P. Morgan, 2025

The LP facilitates the IOE transaction by managing the FX risk in the OTC market and is responsible for making sure the transaction is fully documented via trade confirmation. The crucial feature of the IOE workflow, distinguishing it from a prohibited transitory EFRP, is that the offsetting physical transaction is not contingent upon the FX EFP transaction in any way. [7]

As investors have expressed interest in off- book and listed liquidity, LPs are introducing improved product offerings to allow for customization and interoperability between listed and OTC structures. In addition, the advancement of electronic FX execution is beginning to incorporate automation via direct API or single dealer platforms.

To the extent that interest in EFRPs expands, we expect to see continued growth in FX futures volumes. [8] Market participants keen on managing the operational and regulatory challenges associated with holding uncleared OTC risk will be closely monitoring the evolution of blocks, EFRPs, and their impact on FX liquidity, as these elements shape the future of the market.

Market structure change in credit trading has been unfolding rapidly. The growth of electronic trading across high yield and investment grade markets has been driven by the development of execution protocols for corporate bond trading. As the market evolves, there is appetite for new tools to navigate emerging liquidity pools. Coinciding with these shifts in the execution landscape, credit futures are gaining momentum.

Unlike bond futures, which settle on a cash price of the bond (with a factor adjustment), credit index futures are cash settled and facilitate unfunded exposure to the underlying total return corporate bond index. This provides investors with exposure to both the spread and rate components to the bonds, where all the coupons are reinvested at the end of the month.

Initially developed in 2015 to provide a standardized method for trading 5- year credit index futures, the early version of this product did not catch on with market participants. [10] However, the product offering has since expanded, with contracts now trading on three global exchanges and tracking an underlying index by either Bloomberg or S&P iBoxx.
Figure 6: Credit futures contracts

Market SegmentExchangeCurrencyUnderlying NameFuture TickerBBG TickerLaunch DateSettlementMultiplierInvestment GradeEurexEURBBG MSCI Euro Corp SRIFECXLXY27-Sep-21Third Friday1000EurexUSDBBG US CorpFUIGBBE23-Sep-24Third Friday25CBOEUSDiBoxx iShares $IG CorpIBIGIHB8-Oct-18First business day1000CMEUSDBBG US CorpQIBIQB17-Jun-24Third Wednesday30High YieldEurexGBPBBG Sterling Liquid CorpFGBCXZR5-Feb-24Third Friday200EurexEURBBG Liquidity Screened Euro HYFEHYAHW17-Oct-22Third Friday200EurexUSDBBG VLI: HYFUHYBBL23-Sep-24Third Friday100CBOEUSDiBoxx iShares $HY CorpIBHYIBY10-Sep-18First business day1000IG - HedgedCMEUSDBloomberg VLI: HYBYHHYB17-Jun-24Third Wednesday150HY - HedgedCMEUSDBBG US Corp Dur HedgedDHBDHB17-Jun-24Third Wednesday500BBG VLI: HY Dur HedgedDHYDHY17-Mar-25Third Wednesday750
Source: J.P. Morgan, 2025

CBOE, CME and Eurex offer credit index futures, the majority of which reference USD investment grade (IG) and high yield (HY) indices. For market participants looking to manage duration risk, there is a duration-hedged USD product that offers exposure to the credit spread component of the total return while stripping out the rates component.[11]
Figure 7: USD credit futures open interest (USD million), January 2023-July 2025
Sources: J.P. Morgan, BBG, CME, Eurex, CBOE, 2025.

Eurex also lists futures on Euro and Sterling IG and Euro HY indices. While the EUR IG futures currently has the highest open interest and average daily trading volume among credit futures contracts, the comparatively flat growth trajectory may reflect the fact that the FI ETF market is not as substantial as in the US.
**Figure 8:** EUR and GBP credit futures open interest (million), January 2023-July 2025
Sources: J.P.Morgan, Eurex,2025.

Aggregating across all available products, credit index futures activity has notably increased; open interest passed \(\) 4.5\(billion and average daily volumes have approached\) \ \(1\) billion. [12] This improved liquidity reflects the confluence of evolving investor preferences and technological advancement, with a range of conceivable outcomes. To the extent that derivatives market experts leverage index futures to gain corporate bond exposure, there may be an influx of participants into credit markets resulting in a more diverse trading landscape. For existing credit traders, futures may present additional options for navigating a variety of market conditions.

The growing significance of macro credit products has been a defining trend in global corporate bond markets. Alongside the electrification of credit trading, the mechanisms used for market access are diversifying. The embrace of portfolio trading, exchange- traded funds (ETFs) and credit derivatives has contributed to record trading volumes during the first half of 2025, as market liquidity and breadth have been resilient despite elevated volatility. [13]

As part of a growing trading toolkit, credit index futures represent an interesting mechanism for existing credit market participants. While futures typically reference similar markets to other instruments such as credit ETFs, total return swaps (TRS) or credit default swaps (CDS) indices, several features differentiate these products.
Figure 9: Credit instruments comparison
FuturesETFsTRSCDS/CDXReturnTotalTotalTotalSpreadUnfundedXInterest rateXShortedBorrow must be locatedListedXX
Source: J.P. Morgan, 2025

Credit futures incorporate financing costs directly. The pricing of a future is based on the cost of financing a replicating basket for the underlying index from trade date to expiry. This creates an unfunded index position, where being long the future equates to
being long the underlying and funding the position, resulting in the future “underperforming” the index by the cost of funding.

This structure, which differs from ETFs that require a separate funding leg, may be useful for liquidity and cash management. Unlike ETFs, no management fees are associated with futures, making them a cost- effective tool for tracking corporate bond benchmarks.

Traders are also considering the value of credit futures for hedging against defaults and fluctuations in credit spreads. Because they provide exposure to the credit indices rather than the individual bonds, credit futures can be useful for risk management and portfolio overlay strategies, allowing market participants to adjust positions quicker during periods of volatility or challenging liquidity.

For asset managers or multi- asset funds looking for beta replication of an index, the credit futures product presents an avenue for engaging with the global corporate bond market, with access to liquidity expanding beyond U.S. credit products and offering exposure to international markets. The ability to trade futures on margin can attract those seeking to take levered or short positions.

Mirroring the shift observed in FX markets, potential cost savings are driving adoption and open interest. Credit futures also introduce margin offsets, enabling cross- product netting to further optimize capital efficiency.

On exchange: Most of the volume takes place on the electronic central limit order book, where clients access liquidity from many LPs. In certain cases, agency TWAP/VWAP executions are traded on screen, although liquidity is comparatively limited.

Off- exchange: Credit futures can also be traded off- exchange using various OTC execution methods. One option is to execute a risk block trade, where the risk price is negotiated between a customer and the LP.

More recently, derived block trades have generated interest among certain market participants. Derived blocks are a concept more commonly associated with equity index trading, where the price and quantity of the trade depends on hedging transactions in a related market, such as ETFs. Parties to the trade agree on a basis price to be added to the hedged index price, resulting in the final futures price. [14]

Credit market investors have also been considering another equity concept, the basis trade at index close (BTC). In that trade, a buyer and seller agree to trade futures contracts, but rather than agree to a specific price, they agree to a spread, or basis, to be added to that day's closing index level to determine the futures price.

Separately, credit futures can be executed as an EFP transaction, where parties exchange the futures position for an equivalent position in the underlying credit instrument. We observe market participants using EFPs for carry trades that involve a long cash and short futures position.

For investors seeking portfolio diversification and EM exposure, emerging market credit futures are in focus. Though liquidity is still developing, multiple EM credit futures products are now available, providing exposure to U.S. dollar- denominated sovereign and sub- sovereign debt.
- CBOE iBoxx Emerging Market Bond Index Futures (IEMD)- Eurex Bloomberg Emerging Market USD Sovereign and Sovereign Owned Index Futures (FUEM)
EM credit futures may be a consideration for relative value strategies between total return swaps and other credit derivatives, given the IM savings compared with CDS Indices.

Looking ahead, new use cases and increased activity could drive further behavioral shifts in credit markets, such as a movement of options activity from ETFs to futures. Shifting competitive dynamics will be another aspect to monitor if derivatives trading brings new players into the credit ecosystem. As fixed income markets incorporate an expanded set of trading solutions, the credit futures segment appears poised for continued growth.

Despite being in the comparatively early stages, the momentum of exchange- traded derivatives is also evident in the commodities market, with the introduction of index products. Indexes have been effective for providing participants with broad exposure to global commodity prices, with the Bloomberg Commodity Index (BCOM)[15] and the Standard & Poor's Goldman Sachs Commodity Index (GSCI)[16] being the most prevalent.

These products were slow to catch on due to high costs and limited liquidity, but that appears to be changing. In recent years, exchange operators such as CME have developed several commodity index futures and cleared swaps with exposure to BCOM and GSCI.[17]
Figure 10: CME commodity index futures open interest (USD million)

More recently, CME has launched sub- indices that track a particular sector and provide exposure to a more granular subset of the overall BCOM Index, allowing for sector- specific views and hedging. [18] As we have seen with other asset classes discussed above, the search for capital efficiencies could be a key growth driver here. Commodity sub- indices may be seen as an avenue to obtain margin offsets across a range of other commodity futures positions, including other sub- index futures, commodity index futures in general and the underlying individual futures positions.

While it is still unclear whether these index futures will prompt sustained growth in open interest, the product development demonstrates an emphasis on margin costs and central clearing in commodities markets.

Driven by regulatory changes and technological advancements, the growing focus on listed derivatives is notable. With increased awareness of products such as EFRPs, credit futures and commodity index futures, market participants are incorporating these tools into the toolkit.

Looking ahead, we expect the emphasis on margin efficiency and portfolio optimization to develop further, shifting the way market participants engage and interact with liquidity. For any inquiries related to the topics set out in this report, please contact the FICC Market Structure team or your J.P. Morgan sales representative.
